description: There is a permissive yellow at this intersection (for motorists turning left from Raleigh Rd onto Burning Tree Dr) in effect while the pedestrian signal is active. A rise in the road limits the motorists' view of oncoming traffic, which results in them making turns hastily and not taking time to look for pedestrians. This is in an elementary school walk zone at the head of a multiuse path.

There are no crosswalks at this four way stop. Three of the parcels are town-owned, including a playground, picnic area, and tennis courts. Drivers routinely blow through the intersection, making it a dangerous place for kids trying to access the public amenities here. The intersection is also in a walk zone for an elementary school.

The extra lanes at this intersection and shape of the road curve result in cars moving far too fast turning onto Mill Rd. with school and city bus stops at this crossing and many pedestrians. My family has had many scary encounters with fast cars coming dangerously close to us.

Most people crossing the road press the button and give up waiting and just cross. But for those who do, if you're pushing a stroller or carrying packages, it's common for the light to have already changed before you reach the other side.

description: There is a hydro pole in the middle of the sidewalk, which means anyone with a mobility device will not be able to use this side of the road.

This intersection needs upgrading and slip lanes need to be removed. Slip lanes are designed to maintain high vehicle speeds around corners which is not conducive to a vibrant or safe pedestrian realm.
There is no safe way to cross Cadboro Bay Rd. to access the beach at the bottom of Tudor.

There is no sidewalk or safe shoulder and cars travel at far to fast a speed down the hill. This is an important walking and cycling connecting for families / children accessing Doncaster Elementary and a connection to the Cedar Hill chip trail.

This intersection has poor visibility due to the hill and hedges so cars crossing or turning left from Cedar Hill X onto Cadboro Bay Rd. must move quickly and without clear sight lines. This creates confusion and many failed attempts by cars to accelerate. The slip lanes allow cars turning to keep high speeds. Cyclists must navigate all this without lanes of any kind. Pedestrians can only cross at the southern side of the intersection; there are no sidewalks on the north side at all.

Parked cars on side of road and no sidewalks create single lane traffic and danger for pedestrians or those using wheelchairs and walkers going between the park (with senior/LTC housing) and the galloping goose trail safe transit to local malls. 
Almost all sidewalks in this area are quite old and unsafe and only a few roads even have sidewalks. In the narrow single lane areas, cars must go behind pedestrians… often leading  to impatience especially when waiting on a pedestrian with a walker.

The alignment of the vehicle entrance to the village plaza parking lot is very awkward in relation to the crosswalk across Penrhyn. Vehicles turning left from Cadboro Bay onto Penrhyn to access the parking lot often cut off pedestrians.

Cars always come speeding up a hill here and can't see above the peak of the hill.  A 30 km speed recommendation for this stretch of road is rarely followed.  Anyone wanting to cross at or around Union Rd has to take their chances and run across Blenkinsop.
Shoulder of road very narrow for walking, no sidewalk, traffic often runs over 30km limit, no signage advising motorists to watch for pedestrians.
There is no safe sidewalk/walkway for pedestrians on the west side of Cadboro Bay Rd between Sinclair and Penrhyn, and no crosswalk on the west side to cross at Penrhyn.
The pedestrian/cycle path into UVic campus from the northwest dumps everyone into the parking lot where they have to contend with cars before accessing the sidewalk on McGill Rd.
Shelbourne speed limit should be reduced to no more than 40 kms/hr because "sidewalk" on West side is totally inadequate (too narrow, too broken up) and could cause falling, tripping into traffic.

Bicycles going north west on Arbutus and then turning left onto Finnerty turn onto the sea rated bike path on the left side of Finnerty but cars turning right from Finnerty to Arbutus assume bikes are going to the vehicle travel lane on the right side of Finnerty. As a result cars turning right almost collide with cyclists turning left
There are shrubs that block the view of pedestrians trying to cross by drivers. Must step out onto roadway to be seen by drivers.
Dangerous Holly bush has overgrown sidewalk at face level.

where the continuation of the bike path from Circle Dr. meets the new Dallas Rd. multi use path. The design standard for the forcemain improvements said that all pedestrian crossings of the bike path would be given with pavement markings. I have had close calls and observed others have them

description: Si nous ne sommes pas directement sur le coin de la rue prêt à traverser, il est impossible de traverser sans courrir ou nous partons sur la main clignotante. Nous obligeant soit à traverser illégalement soit à attendre longtemps (aux quatre-vents) le prochain feu pitéon. Problématique peu sécuritaire considérant la présence de nombreuses résidences pour personnes âgées.

Le positionnement des boutons d'appel semble être inverser. Ils ne sont pas positionner de façon instinctive. C'est à dire qu'on doit dévier de notre axe pour appuyer sur le bouton d'appel pour effectuer notre traversée. Résultat, on appuie sur le mauvais bouton d'appel et on attend longtemps et les piétons s'impatientent et traversent illégalement.

So instead of slowing down and stopping for pedestrians at the marked mid-block crosswalk they often speed up and fail to yield to pedestrians to try to make the light.

description: This is a very wide intersection. Vehicles turn left and right during the pedestrian walk light. If I have any impediment at all, such as slush/ice or if I'm carrying groceries, I cannot cross in the time allotted.
Snow piled up, walkways not cleared, had to walk far too close to speeding traffic. Thrifty foods area was especially bad!

snow not cleared VERY difficult for anyone but mostly people in Wheel Chairs and or walkers, this piece of side walk just Does not get cleared after any snow fall, Jimmy Pattison owns this building. he needs to deal with this
2 huge potholes, dangerous to both cars and bikes

feature_subtype: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)
description: Raised abutment next to sidewalk causing tripping and obstruction for wheelchairs, carts and mobility scooters to get over.
detail: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)

feature_subtype: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)
description: Raised abutment next to sidewalk causing tripping and obstruction for wheelchairs, carts and mobility scooters to get over.
detail: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: Many cars go through the flashing yellow light. Don't even see pedestrians.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description:
The crossing is sloped and wide. You cross two roads and watch for cars turning into and out of Belmont. The slope of the crossing makes it very difficult for people with mobility issues. The steep angle of the road is very intimidating - cars roll down the steep hill towards you.

Drivers exiting Balmoral on to Fort will often block the sidewalk and bike lane.

When it snows or gets icy, people fall here often, which is quite scary because you fall on a slope down to an extremely busy roadway.

This crossing is challenging. The sidewalk is sloped toward a very busy road, which is most concerning when conditions are wet and slippery. The right turn slip lane for east-bound Fort St traffic allows people to turn onto Belmont without slowing down. Traffic exiting Belmont must stop on a steep slope, making crossing very uncomfortable. Traffic at the Fort St junction is often backed up, leading vehicles exiting Belmont to block the sidewalk and bike lane.

Accessing the bike path from Dallas Rd in the west-bound direction is very challenging. Design of Dallas road (wide straight lanes) encourages fast driving. As a cyclist, it is necessary to take the lane at the blind corner on Dallas, to safely make the left to the path entrance. The volume and speed of traffic can make it difficult to find an opening to make the turn. This frequently elicits aggressive behaviour from people driving behind me, who may not understand what I’m trying to do.
No street light in area, many pedestrians at night.

Braefoot Park is a Saanich Park yet the sidewalk on McKenzie Avenue adjacent to the property was not cleared of snow throughout Dec 24-January 4. Interestingly, the parking lot was completely clear, plowed, and salted.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: Speeding here is rampant! Very sketchy crossing in the early morning or at dusk or pm. Many commuters short-cutting and race the light, not paying attention. Kids use crossing every weekday.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: This is a marked 30km zone but most vehicles don't follow this.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: While this intersection has been made a 4 way stop, many drivers don't at all. Some will enter the intersection while one is crossing. Others will display their displeasure of having to wait 15 seconds while one is walking in the crosswalk.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: Neither the province or town plow the sidewalk along Six Mile Rd.
The strata on Carly lane plow their snow and blocks the sidewalk during winter weather

A strip of unpainted asphalt has been placed in the  shoulder/bike lane that is a hazard to cyclists and walkers. It appears as if the asphalt was placed to keep vehicles from cutting the corner into the bus stop area.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: It's a 4 way stop and a lot of drivers don't stop. Pedestrians please be cautious. There is a stop light a block down on Sussex ave. You might want to cross there instead.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: This path leads to Claremont school. A speed bump slows cars but they are not aware that children cross here frequently.

There are no sidewalks and no lighting on this block.  The road is narrow and cars come flying around the corner quickly.  This road is accessed by youth, children and families on foot walking to the Recreation park facilities and schools on the next block.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: There is a stop for vehicles coming down the hill, but about 40% of them fail to stop properly. This is because it is really a corner and not an intersection. The two sub division residents have to drive along way into/out of the neighbourhood at 30 KPH and feel that the stop is a waste of their time, since it shouldn't be there in the first place.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: There is a lot of trees and a stop/crossing on a property that block the view to the for drivesrs coming from Lund onto Chilco the obscures the view to the right. Traffic
It's dark. Lights are off every night.
Long, straight stretch of road encourages speeding.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: Drivers coming off of Pear st and onto Shelbourne making a turn in any direction rarely check if the crosswalk is clear before doing so. On numerous occasions, I have almost been hit by a car while crossing on a walk signal.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: This is a four-way stop. Drivers are often too focused on other cars and the order of movement to notice any pedestrians in the crosswalks. There's also a very busy bus stop here, which creates a lot of pedestrian traffic and a lot of space for potential incidents.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: This intersection cluster was created by someone who seems to have no regard for anyone not in a car. Signals are often unclear and take a very long time to repeat, so what should be a 10-sec crossing turns into at least 3-5min of waiting as cars go. People on bikes or in wheelchairs are often at higher risk here as the pedestrian areas are much lower to the street, encouraging cars to come as close as possible to people who may not be able to move away quickly.
No sidewalk at all. Cars speed through here as a shortcut and there is literally no sidewalk anywhere

There are 2 issues at this intersection. 1 - The pedestrian crossing light between the trail out of Rainbow park crossing Mackenzie to Douglas is too short. Cyclists crossing Mackenzie from Douglas to the Rainbow Park trail have to cross the traffic and ride the wrong way in the Douglas bike lane to access the button to activate the crosswalk light because there is no in road or other method of activating the light for crossing Mackenzie.

An official labelled bike route on Dieppe Road brings North bound cyclists onto the sidewalk on Quadra St. The crosswalk button delays the green light on Chatterton for a few seconds after the lights turn red on Quadra which is great for pedestrians crossing at the sidewalk and also permits cyclists to cross North bound to Chatterton in the correct lane from the driveway on the south side of Quadra. However, there is no signage either for drivers or cyclists that this crossing is possible.

An unmarked raised pavement curb intended to redirect water flow on the road has been built across the bike lane. The pavement is a hazard to cyclists and anyone else who may be using a wheel chair because they are forced into traffic.

The bollard at the start of the bike lane where the Johnson Street offramp meets Wharf Street heading east then south is both confusing and hazardous. The space on the bike path is too narrow to navigate and the bollard itself is a crashing hazard. It is also unclear on how the cyclist is to navigate, which side of the bollard one should take.
No let down for sidewalks on Cadboro Bay either side of Killarney. Strollers and elderly very hard to navigate.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: Extreme level of traffic through the village now. Most times I walk through cars not leaving room for pedestrians, proceeding through crosswalk right behind people etc.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description:
Crossing Cadboro Bay Rd by bike is very difficult. The road is very wide so traffic moves very fast. Crossing from the Cedar Hill Rd side is made worse by a corner, hedges and hill. It nearly impossible to know when there is a safe gap in traffic. Additionally there are multiple slip lanes which encourage high speed turns and merged by cars.

This is easily one of the least safe places to bike which is ridiculous because it's a major cycling route to the university and for sport riding.

The sidewalk has no buffer from the road. There is a lot of traffic that moves quite fast. When walking on the inside of this corner, vehicles moving in excess of 50km/h come within a foot or less of you. It's extremely uncomfortable to walk here. You can sometimes feel the wind off the vehicles passing you by!

Foul Bay is very narrow between Milton St and Oak Bay Ave. There is a lot of street parking and there is no bike lane. Traffic is heavy and often impatient. I often am passed unsafely or get harassed for taking the lane during this section.

This area is very constrained for space, leaving few options. An ideal solution would be a few mini roundabouts. This would stop high speeds/passing that is encouraged by the straight road design. It would also improve the space for pedestrians and eliminate the need for traffic lights.


These streets are designed like highways for no purpose. They connect to narrower sections but around this area are extremely wide and multi-lane.

The crosswalks are very long because of the trapezoid shape of the intersection. Also, you have to wait for long periods of time because the crossing light runs every 4 cycles, unlike most intersections which have 2 cycles. This makes for a very frustrating area to cross and encourages frequent jaywalking for preferred paths.

Richmond traffic is often high speed and high volume. The side walk has no buffer from the road. In addition to that, this particular area lacks a marked side walk and has a parking space which often results in local residents parking in the path of the sidewalk, forcing pedestrians to walk IN the path of the high speed Richmond traffic.

I have often had very uncomfortable moments here as I've had to walk in the road to get around a parked car.

This area is popular with sightseeing motorists. It is also really popular for cyclists. This particular area often has conflicts with motorists wanting to pass unsafely. Far more traffic volume passes through here than can be justified by the residences here and it is unnecessary given the other route options.

Riding a bike along here is very uncomfortable. There is often a high traffic volume and the wide, straight lanes encourage high speeds. People driving are often impatient and aggressive. Street parking forces people on bikes to choose between the risk of being doored or being harassed/passed dangerously by vehicles. Signage marks this as a “bike route” but there is no supporting infrastructure.

This section of Dallas road is straight and wide, encouraging unsafe vehicle speeds. There is no buffer between the sidewalk and the road, making walking along the sidewalk very uncomfortable. I usually opt to walk through the cemetery to avoid this, which is a shame since it’s a beautiful shoreline.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: The large corner radii at this intersection allow vehicles entering St Charles from Fort or exiting St Charles onto Fort to make right turns at dangerous speed and also increase the crossing distance for pedestrians. Vehicles exiting St Charles frequently stop well into the crosswalk. Power lines in the sidewalk and vehicles in the crosswalk block visibility of people crossing.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

feature_subtype: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)
description: Too many uneven cracks.
detail: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)

description:
This is a very dangerous intersection. Motorists turning east onto Belleville from Government routinely charge and intimidate me as I am trying to cross the street.

I live in James Bay. I walk up Government to go to the dentist, do banking, buy stuff at Murchies for birthdays, get kids clothes at Bay Centre, all that sort of thing.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: Motorists traveling west on Toronto Street routinely charge me as I am crossing here.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: Sidewalk here and the corner waiting area is tiny and difficult to have two people walking side by side, add a couple dogs and there is no way to safely navigate.  This sidewalk and corner pedestrian areas are inadequate for the number and speed of vehicle coming by and around the corner.
The bus stop is right next to the road with no sidewalk to get to it or even at the bus stop it self. Vehicles are traveling at a high speed in the area.

This is a common route for people leaving UVic campus by bike or on foot. Street parking blocks visibility of traffic along Cedar hill X road, making crossing challenging. This is worsened by vehicle speeds, which are often fast along this road.

The right turn slip lane from Cedar Hill X onto Cadboro Bay presents a challenge for people on bikes going straight onto Upper Terrace. The slip lane allows vehicles to begin the turn at high speeds. Bikes going straight through must either take the lane early and risk harassment, or be cut off by high speed right turn traffic.

Signage marks Beach Drive north of Cattle point as a “bike route” yet the posted speed limit is 50 km/hr. The survival rate for people hit by vehicles traveling this speed is 20%. Reducing the speed of vehicles along Beach Drive between Cattle point and Cadboro Bay could improve comfort and safety for both people walking and cycling, making this a genuine bike route for people of all abilities.

The multiple slip lanes at this intersection increase crossing distances unnecessarily for pedestrians and allow vehicles to make right turns to and from Windsor Rd without slowing. This makes crossing very uncomfortable for people walking. Riding a bike past this intersection southbound on Beach Drive is also hazardous because of the complexity and speed of turning vehicles.

Vehicle speeds along Oak Bay are often dangerously fast. This is unsurprising, given that vehicle lanes are approximately 7 m. Even with street parking (which isn’t consistently present), this leaves well over 3.7 m lanes in each direction, which is the recommended lane width for Canadian highways and expressways. Why does a residential and commercial street have wider lanes than a highway?
No crosswalk, no traffic calming, no lights, poor signage. People (school kids) j-walking.
There are many elders and people with mobility issues who live in the area. When crossing Veterans Memorial Pkwy, the pedestrian light will often turn red before I can get to the other side.
There are no sidewalks at all.
Curvy bus route no sidewalk or safe bike path   Fast moving traffic

The section of Fort between Cook and Yates is a drag strip. Vehicle speeds are high, and people driving routinely jockey to be at the front of the pack before the street narrows to one lane at Yates. This makes being outside of a vehicle or crossing incredibly uncomfortable, especially when the sidewalk is closed and people have to walk in the bike lane. Are two through lanes really necessary?

This intersection is massively overbuilt. This results in long crossing distances for pedestrians and encourages dangerous vehicle speeds. The corner radius from Cowichan onto Richardson is huge, making the crossing distance for pedestrians about 30 meters! The slip lane onto Runnymede creates a sidewalk that is not accessible for people with disabilities or strollers.

We need safe bus stops with sidewalks on this side of Tanner Rd. It is ridiculous that any of bus stops on this side of Tanner are acceptable. This is a residential area in which it can be fairly dangerous just to go for a walk or catch a bus.
Why this overapass has the switchback at both ends, why this overpass has sharp 90 degree corners.
There is no sidewalk and a blind corner. People turning off charters onto sooke road are not aware of people walking the other direction. People often roll through the stop.
There is a curb in the bike lane.
Our family wants to let our daughter walk to school but she has no crosswalk and it's busy in the mornings and summers during camping season.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: Most vehicles do not stop for pedestrians at this crosswalk due to excessive speed when driving up and down Cedar Hill Rd.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

feature_subtype: obstruction - inadequate or lack of safe detour for pedestrians
description: Vehicle often parked closed to the corner of this narrow two lane road - no room for pedestrians.
detail: obstruction - inadequate or lack of safe detour for pedestrians

description: Trail enters roadway at sharp corner with very limited visibility (poor design).  Most pedestrians ignore croswalk and cut across corner increasing the likelihood of a serious incident.

Parking on the street on a corner makes it dangerous for pedestrians as there is no sidewalk and it is a tight corner.  Vehicles parked there force walkers into the traffic lane and it is on a tight corner.

feature_subtype: obstruction - inadequate or lack of safe detour for pedestrians
description: The sidewalk is frequently closed at this location due to construction and pedestrians are routed into the road. Vehicle speeds along this stretch of Fort are fast. It is really uncomfortable having to walk within feet of high speed traffic.
detail: obstruction - inadequate or lack of safe detour for pedestrians

description: Cars coming down Langvista Hill do not come to a full stop at the stop sign before poking out onto Mill Hill to check for oncoming traffic. There is a large hedge that impedes vision and drivers come down the hill too fast. Pedestrians crossing the road are in danger of being hit.
Traffic travels too fast and fails to yield to cyclists taking the lane or pedestrians in the crosswalk.

If you walk along the path you see lines through the grass on both sides of the highway, indicating that many people a day cross the highway here.  It is only a matter of time before someone is killed here
Speed of vehicles is too high for cars going around this corner. Many young families in this neighbourhood accessing the park- crossing from Mellville park to Resthaven park.
No speed limit signs. Cars consistently at 60km hr. Several accidents.
Fulton Road feels very unsafe to walk on. Cars go very fast and there are no sidewalks.
Poor visibility (hill), narrow shoulders and vehicles going too fast make this area dangerous for pedestrians and cyclists with cars passing very near or having to stop.
There is no room for a wheelchairs or stroller to go behind the bus shelter, but can’t go in front of it because of the pole and trash can.

A new path from new Royal Bay Meadow development has been extended up to Wishart Road directly across from an existing path/stairway to Tory Place which will encourage pedestrians crossing at this location at one end of a curve in Wishart Road. Colwood has not provided new crosswalk markings, new crossing lights or new signage. This stretch of Wishart has no housing or driveways facing the street and drivers often increase their speed.
This is a sharp corner with poor visibility, poles on both sides (one is actually on the road), cement barriers covered in moss, poor markings and no room for bikes or pedestrians.
Vehicles travel at high rate of speed, often close to pedestrians.  Pedestrians forced to walk in bike lane, where it exists at all, or on a small shoulder.

There is absolutely no shoulder, side walk, cross walk or bike lane in this area. Most of Latoria does not have a safe place to walk or cycle. It is nearly impossible to get from our home to the Galloping goose to ride safely.

Sidewalk (from Seaton crossing to Tillicum Elementary school) is quite narrow, with no bike lanes or buffer between pedestrians and fast moving vehicles. Also, many telephone poles inside limited sidewalk space. (Speeds are typically 60+km/h) and this is supposed to be a ‘safe’ route to school??

The path goes nicely along and then it’s so narrow and by the time you find out there is no room to turn around. A couple of strangers took pity on me and actually held one side of my motorized wheelchair till the path got wider but then the sidewalk had no way to get off the sidewalk.
Way too steep! It’s dangerous it’s so steep!

Crossing to the bus eastbound bus stop requires crossing an unmarked/implied crosswalk. Drivers unfortunately don't stop for pedestrians, even when they are halfway across the road. Additionally, there is no crosswalks on the south side of the road, meaning crossing at Latoria/Castlewood is the only option. Finally, drivers speed around the road, and the curving nature of the road reduces visibility of oncoming cars.

Pedestrians are forced to step into the right hand turn lane to see past the massive hedge on the neighbouring property. There is no safe way to walk through this intersection. To walk along Luxton road, pedestrians must walk in the road, or through a hedge. There's also no crosswalks. To make matters worse, there is a pair of bus stops at this intersections. Pedestrians were entirely ignored when this was built.

The bus stop at Latoria and Klahanie is inaccessible to everyone, and requires the buses to block the intersection to properly use the doors and ramp.There is no crossing to the twin stop in the other direction, and there is no considerations for pedestrians. There is a painted bike lane between the car lane and a jersey barrier. There is no room to walk outside the jersey barrier. This design is dangerous for cyclists as they exposed to cars, and pedestrians have no room to walk.
Sidewalks on Shelbourne are too narrow, and too close to car traffic, making for an uncomfortable and unsafe pedestrian experience.

Awful bike lane design. Bike lane turns into a right turn only lane. To go straight and continue down cloverdale bike lane, bikes must cross a lane of traffic to enter the general vehicle lane. Or disobey right turn only markings and risk a "right hook" by turning drivers.
Southbound bike lane pavement is in poor condition and often full of debris. Can be dangerous with narrow lanes and fast moving traffic

No bike lane most of the way up and all of the way down the hill. dark hill with no bike lane and only one sidewalk. Bikers are always very slow going up causing cars to go around into oncoming traffic adding more risk.

The bike lane Literally disappears in the small stretch of road beside rendle green. There is a bike lane going up the hill on cedar hill crossroad to Richmond Road then disappears for 30m then starts up again after poplar ave. There is no notice that the bike lane ends until a biker is just right in front of you while driving.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: Drivers turning left from west side of Pear St do not yield to pedestrians crossing on south crosswalk. They often encroach onto the crosswalk and block oncoming traffic to intimidate pedestrians to move through the crosswalk faster.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: Drivers do not stop at crosswalk
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: Drivers are too focused on merging with Cedar Hill traffic combined with poor visibility from neighboring hedge.

The sidewalk is very narrow. Since the road is narrow here too, the cars drive very close to the edge of the sidewalk. Big trucks almost overhang the sidewalk when they go by. There is nowhere to go to get out of the way since there is a retaining wall.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: Cars rarely stop when turning right. Often blast through the stop sign very fast to catch a break in traffic. I have almost been hit here many times, and so have my friends.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: Shelbourne is a deathtrap for people on bikes. There is no protected lanes, or even any painted lanes, and lacks any safe alternatives.

This corner can be very dangerous to take on a bike especially in the morning. There are lots of large commercial dump trucks and freight vehicles who are forced to cut this corner making it very risky for cyclists.

I am concerned that the new bike lanes make gaining this intersection on a bike risky. Going straight on government in either direction requires cars turningright to yield to cyclist. I am concerned that many cars will not yield. Secondly, the slip lane coming off bay on to government adds risk to cyclist coming going straight on government.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: Lack of crosswalk on bee street forces pedestrians to cross the road in an unsafe manner. Vehicles are supposed to yield to pedestrians especially since the street is near a recreation center. A vehicle didn't yield while I was crossing the street. In fact, it was speeding towards me and I had to run to avoid nearly getting hit by it.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

feature_subtype: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)
description: Uneven sidewalk surfaces, seams between concrete slabs... Edges have lifted a bit too much. Watched a skateboarder bail when his wheels hit one of these edges. About 10 to 15 feet from the side of the market by the medical clinic / drugstore.
detail: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)

description: These are no bike lanes, sidewalks, crosswalks or other amenities for pedestrians or bikers.  Turning left across Happy valley to Lactoria on a bike is nearly impossible at peek traffic hours in the morning and late afternoon.
The visibility around this sharp corner is very bad, that compounded by the lack of sidewalks or bike lane make it very unsafe.
These is no sidewalk or bike lane and this corner has very poor visibility.

feature_subtype: obstruction - inadequate or lack of safe detour for pedestrians
description: There has been ongoing construction blocking the bike lanes in this area for almost a full year now. I try to avoid the goose in the mornings since I commute via ebike and am usually going a lot faster than the people walking along the goose.
detail: obstruction - inadequate or lack of safe detour for pedestrians

description: Cut through to a pathway but no crosswalk or curb cut.
This is a weird light. The signal is super responsive but the timing is very short.

Rockland between Moss and Oak Bay has a single, unprotected sidewalk (i.e. it has no buffer between the sidewalk and moving vehicles) along the south side of the street. Despite the low speed limit, people commonly speed along here. The lack of a buffer between moving vehicles and the sidewalk can make walking along here very uncomfortable.

The sidewalk here is heavily trafficked as students arrive and leave school, and too narrow for the volume. Lots of people riding bikes on it at those times too, as Old Island isn't very safe to bike on / turn on to
No one seems to clear the sidewalk between Admirals and Shoreline after a snow.
Vehicles approaching westbound on Cook at high speeds. Would like to see a rumble strip or pedestrian island, like on kitty corner Chevron station.

There is a very busy trail that connects here to the beach trail. I have nearly been hit several times crossing the road here as there is no crosswalk and it has a bit of a blind bend. As a driver I have nearly had incidents here too. Busy road intersecting with a busy trail. I always worry someone is going to get hurt here.
Road is very narrow, no sidewalks, in summer alot of trafficking obeying speed limits

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: Busy crosswalk with lots of young children walking to and from school and Douglas Park. Cars do not stop to let pedestrians cross, and visibility of crosswalk is very limited due to parked cars.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: The unprotected sidewalks along Lansdowne are really uncomfortable to walk along. The vehicle lanes are excessively wide, which unsurprisingly leads to people driving at dangerous speeds. There are rarely vehicles parked on the street, so people on the sidewalk have no protection. Sometimes people driving will whizz by so close and quickly that you can feel the wind from their vehicle!

Drivers who plan to turn right onto the highway after the Peatt Rd intersection frequently stop in the bike lane. This blocks cyclists trying to reach the intersection and puts them at risk of right hook collisions if the cyclist tries to pass the car.
Cars sometimes drift into the bike lane. This makes cyclists uncomfortable and puts them at risk of collision.

feature_subtype: signal - wait time to cross too long
description: It’s unclear why a beg button and traffic light are needed here. People walking have to cue up and wait for what feels like a really long time for permission to cross. The green light encourages people to drive through the intersection at dangerous speeds. A controlled crossing like this would make sense along an arterial roadway but seems antithetical to a vibrant village.
detail: signal - wait time to cross too long

description: The sidewalk on the south side of Fort, between Yates and the Junction, is way too narrow given the number of people who walk along here. People often have to walk in the road to get around one another. On numerous occasions, I’ve seen elderly people or people with strollers opting to use the bike lane because it is too challenging to navigate around the hydro poles in the sidewalk.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: Unless you're assertive about crossing here, most people driving will not stop for you. I routinely see timid people waiting to cross while numerous vehicles speed by. I understand why people feel timid here. It is stressful asserting your intention to cross the street when a large box of metal and glass is speeding toward you, especially if you have a mobility limitation, a child or a dog.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: None. Super dangerous

This intersection is really uncomfortable to cross. The corners have large radii and are flowy, allowing vehicles to turn at dangerous speeds. This also increases the crossing distance for people walking. You can shorten the crossing distance by walking out of the way down Crescent, but this makes you less visible to turning vehicles.

King George Terrace is often used by people walking and running. It only has one sidewalk on the south side, which is very narrow and unprotected from traffic. People often drive quickly along here, and it is really uncomfortable being so close to moving vehicles. People walking also have to use the road to get around one another.
Super dangerous intersection where you can't see ongoing traffic and feel pressured when making left hand turns, so pedestrians aren't always seen.

feature_subtype: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)
description: Due to construction the sidewalk is destroyed. The surface is uneven and pathway narrow so that it is hazardous to people with mobility issues and those using walkers, canes or scooters. I have seen people in scooters having to ride along Goldstream Ave, as they cannot use the pre-existing sidewalk.
detail: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: I use this crosswalk almost every day. I can have a reflector on, a headlamp, lights on my dogs and still cars do not stop.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description:
This crosswalk is on a very narrow stretch of road and has no lights. As a driver, myself, I see this crosswalk so I am unsure why so many drivers whip through this section.
I walk my dogs every day and cross here and I feel very unsafe 75% of the time.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

feature_subtype: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)
description: Parts of the concrete has broken off over time. Also you cannot pass with a stroller as the sidewalk is barely wide enough for 2 pedestrians to safely pass.
detail: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)

description: Too narrow for two wheeled transport units (wheelchairs, strollers, ect.) to pass on this section of sidewalk.

feature_subtype: obstruction - inadequate or lack of safe detour for pedestrians
description: Sidewalk is closed on this side of the road and the other side is inadequate for the needed travel on foot or wheels.
detail: obstruction - inadequate or lack of safe detour for pedestrians

description: Disability ramp blocked by parking spot

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: No pedestrian controlled crosswalk
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: Walking past the Fairfield plaza parking lot exit on the west side of St Charles is hazardous because vision of the sidewalk is obscured by bushes. People exiting in their cars often do not drive expecting people crossing, and will stop well into the sidewalk. I’ve nearly been hit here a few times by people speeding out of the parking lot, who were only paying attention to the road.
This intersection is so large and vehicles travel very quickly. There isn't enough space for all the kids an bikes and foot before and after school.

Coming from south, it is very difficult to judge whether there are cars approaching from the left. There is no sidewalk to look past the house and the mirror might be useful for cars, but is not useful for pedestrians.

The bend in the road at this spot presents a danger for people riding bikes southbound on Beach Drive. There are often cars parked on the street, making the street narrow. It is uphill, making it challenging to take the lane without harassment. People will often drive at high speed and try passing around the blind corner with no visibility.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: Crossing here is really uncomfortable, despite the marked crosswalk with flashing lights. People drive fast along Richmond and often behave as though you cannot cross until you’ve pressed the button. This makes the pedestrian-activated signal feel like an anti-feature, encouraging people to drive faster toward the crosswalk so they can get there before you, instead of preparing to stop.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: Vehicles speeding along Glen Lake Rd in vicinity of stadium, playground and high school.  Lots of pedestrian traffic in this area.

Many motorcycles, classic cars, hotrods, and heavy vehicles speed down this road.  Probably because it's so straight and long.  Electronic speeding sensor sign nor centre  island does not dissuade them.
Too many RV, commercial vehicles, or trailers like to park in the gravel shoulder next to rail line.
too secluded.  Perfect place for an ambush.  Graffiti is often found here due to it's seclusion.
secluded location that often has graffiti in it.

Despite having a pedestrian activated light, vehicles DON’T stop; especially the north bound vehicles. This crosswalk needs to be looked at because something seems to be wrong. The flashing lights are visible from a long way off and yet cars still don’t stop. I had the misfortune to witness two girls get hit by a car heading north a few years ago and cars are still blowing through

feature_subtype: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)

description: Bike lane turns into a bike turning lane and cyclists have to cross a vehicle turning lane to continue going straight on the parkway. This turning lane is busy and often vehicles are going fast. This section can be confusing as well because the straight section of the bike lane is faded and the turning is still bright green. Sometimes cars don’t think cyclists are supposed to be on that section of the road.

The sidewalk along St Charles between Richardson and Fort is unprotected and vehicle speeds are often dangerously fast. This makes walking along St Charles very uncomfortable. The east side of St Charles between Despard and Rockland is especially threatening. People driving often speed up the hill and drive very close to the sidewalk.

Many people use this section of St Charles as a walking route. Hydro poles, overgrown hedges, and fences/stone walls contribute to making the sidewalk too narrow. People walking often have to go into the road. This is challenging for people with walkers, strollers or dogs.
When turning right from Dressler onto Wishart, cars parked along the side of Wishart make it impossible to see if anything is coming.
There is no open access for the public.. you get trapped and have to turn around towards Glen Lake!

the default speed limit for this road is 50 km/hr (the recommended speed limit is 30, but that is not enforceable). For a narrow (1.5 to single lane) road, 50 is just too fast -  especially since it has very limited visibility (due to hills and turns) and there is no space for a sidewalk or bike lane, so vulnerable road users must walk on the pavement.

description: Despite this being a residential area and destination for people outside of cars, this street encourages through traffic and often has a very high volume of vehicles. Walking along Shelbourne is incredibly uncomfortable. The sidewalks are too narrow and are unprotected from high speed traffic. There are few alternative route options for people walking. Shelbourne between Hillside and Feltham really doesn’t need so many vehicle lanes. It encourages unsafe driving and takes space that could be used to safely accommodate people walking and riding bikes.
No sidewalk, landscaping, and Home Depot has fencing right out to the driveway forcing pedestrians to walk on the busy road

Stunting is common on this part of Connaught Avenue - police have charged drivers going over 150km/hr in the evening and night hours past the Halifax Independent School. Noise from speeding cars is disturbing to residents and poses safety concern to pedestrians and cyclists.

Crossing of multiuser trail and arterial street with elementary school on one side of arterial and large city park on the other. Crossing sits at bottom of a hill in both directions increasing speed of crossing vehicles.

This section of Broad St has a high  volume traffic  traffic that travels at or above posted speed limit. The walkways are not buffered on either side and is incomplete on the other. There is a significant curve that limits sight lines. A continuous center left turn lane is present with very little opportunity to turn left due to few Broad facing businesses.

The east side of Falls Street sidewalk transitions from the new brick Streetscape to the existing narrow sidewalk with large rectangular light poles that make it impassible for people in wheelchairs and people pushing baby strollers. Along the Railyards section of the Goose, there are a number of unsafe crossings where pedestrians are constantly in peril of being hit by a bike. A number of crossings do not have long horizons due to bends in the trail, so pedestrians may think they are safe one minute and all of a sudden they are overtaken by a speeding cyclist. The numbers and speed of bikes in this section have increased dramatically in recent years. The biggest threats are the speed of e-bikes and training groups.

Pedestrians and cyclists walking their bikes often cross the Galloping Goose here. They are often distracted because of trying to locate the washrooms, which causes problems when bikes come speeding past.

There are no lights on the Galloping Goose between Regatta Landing Pier and the Bay St. Bridge. At night, it can get quite dark. Other sections of the Goose have bollards with lights that illuminate the path.

The issue with the sidewalk is that there isn't one. The area in question is the rise and blind corner on this section of the street. description: The crosswalk across third avenue at 19th runs directly into a small island with no curb cuts on either side. Anyone in a wheelchair or walker would have to stay on the road to get across the street.

Curb cut is there but there's a bump making it not as smooth as it should be for people in wheelchairs to be able to move around comfortable. Same at every intersection along Bank.

description: The sidewalk along Warf is far too narrow to support the volume of people walking along here. Navigating around other people on the sidewalk is challenging, making visiting here less desirable. It's common for people walking to spill into the bike lane, creating hazards for both people walking and riding.

The sidewalk here is far too narrow for people walking to comfortably use. The buildings and parked cars create a choke point in the sidewalk that can be challenging to navigate given the volume of people walking. This is particularly insulting given the oversized driving lanes along Oak Bay.

The sidewalk here, on the south side of Oak Bay, is far too narrow for people walking to comfortably use. Many elderly folks with mobility challenges walk along here and people often have to walk in the road to get around one another. The east-bound vehicle lane is almost 8 m wide, making this lack of sufficient sidewalk space particularly insulting.

Dangerous curve, that includes a bridge, for traffic in both directions. Often automobile speed is too high for the curve. Vegetation impedes oncoming traffic both ways. Dicker Rd empties right at the curve at the location of a busstop. There is no room for pedestrians or bicyclists.
Fire hydrant in middle of sidewalk - too narrow for a wheelchair, and going around on the grass isn't really an option.
Uneven sidewalk, poor accessibility for wheelchairs etc.

I barely have enough time to cross the road when being with my toddler. It is an issue since this is used by people going to the daycare nearby.

Crossing from the island to the south side to get to the sidewalk is death defying every time. 

Cars are traveling fast and there is no marked pedestrian crossing.  

Pedestrians are at the mercy for a gap in traffic or drivers.

detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description:
La traverse piétonne est très utilisée par les parents et enfants du CPE juste en face (80 enfants).
Les voitures vont vite, elles arrivent dans les deux sens du boulevard, mais pas seulement. Il y a celles qui tournent de la rue Rielle, mais également celles qui sont temporairement stationnées entre la caserne et le CPE. Mon inquiétude est d'autant plus marquée par la nature des usagers, à savoir de jeunes enfants - parfois à pied, à vélo, en trottinette, accompagnés de leur parent.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: Des travaux (long terme) rendent l'intersection difficile à traverser, et des travaux sur le trottoir côté ouest, au nord de Saint-Vallier, font en sorte qu'une fois qu'on a traversé on ne peut même pas marcher sur le trottoir pour se rendre plus au Nord.

Cette traversée n’est pas sécuritaire aux abords d’une école. Le feu sécurisé n’est assez long et il n’y a aucun brigadier. Les enfants ne sont pas en sécurité. Beaucoup de voitures tournent depuis Rachel ou vers Rachel alors que les piétons traversent.
L’espace aloué pour les vélos est insuffisant et l’angle de vision des véhicules est restreint. Donc très difficile d’éviter les collisions si on dépasse un peu
Need crosswalk for safer school access

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: La traverse piéton permet de traverser la route 112 à partir de la rue Principale pour rejoindre le trottoir de l'autre côté ou sur la rue Blouin. Malgré la présence de panneau indiquant la priorité aux piétons, de même que de lumières clignotantes, il est souvent dangereux de traverser à cet endroit, car les voitures et les camions s'arrêtent trop peu à cette intersection. Des piétons, autant des personnes âgés que des enfants, utilisent cette traverse à leur risques.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: Absence de trottoir. Vitesse élevée des véhicules.
Trottoir pas assez large et d'un seul côté de la rue, vitesse excessive.
Il n'y a pas de trottoir et on traverse l'entrée de 3 commerces qui sont pleine largeur de l'entrée. Dangereux pour les piétons et les cyclistes.
Essais de rapport
Un poteau au milieu du trottoir laisse très peu d'espace pour passer, surtout pour un fauteuil roulant (cette section deviendra probablement impraticable en hiver)

feature_subtype: obstruction - inadequate or lack of safe detour for pedestrians
description: Une partie de la rue est fermée à la circulation automobile pour des travaux, mais les indications ne sont pas claires pour les piétons.
detail: obstruction - inadequate or lack of safe detour for pedestrians

description: Très dangereux, absence de feu piéton

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: cette intersection compte un arrêt d'autobus pour les élèves du secondaire et transport en commun de la ville. malgré des pancartes céder et une traverse piétonnière, plusieurs véhicules ne ralentissent pas, ou n'arrêtent pas a la vue de piétons.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: véhicule tournant a gauche sur Perras a grande vitesse, venant de cité-des-jeunes, tourne malgré un piéton engagé dans le passage piétonnier d'un côté de Perras a l'autre. Cette intersectioon est très achalandée le matin a l'heure de la rentrée des classes,, et dans ce cas il s'agissait d'une jeune conductrice, possiblement une élèeve d'un des 2 cégeps a prxomité, qui garent leur véhicule sur des Églantiers, Perras ou des ormes pour éviter les frais de stationnement.

la jonction entre l'entrée de l'édifice (habitations municipales), le trottoir et la rue se couvre d'eau lors des pluies importantes et de la fonte des neiges, et de glace en hiver. Ceci force les piétons a marcher dans la rue. De nombreuses personnes âgées et èa mobilité réduite habitent l'édifice, et plusieurs enfants circulent sur ce trottoir pour aller a l'école Cote du nord, ou se rendre a la bibliothèque Aurélien doucet

feature_subtype: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)

detail: obstruction - uneven sidewalk (eg. roots, holes, cracks)

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description: À pied j'ai du traverser le chemin tour du lac à deux reprises à cet endroit. Dans les deux cas aucun automobiliste (plus de 10 croisés) ne m'a permis de traverser sur le passage piéton. D'ailleurs le passage piéton est indiqué uniquement sur le pavé aucune autre signalisation sauf une pancarte pour indiquer le dos d'âne. Ici on averti les automobilistes de faire attention à leur voiture pour le dos d'âne mais pas aux usagers vulnérables.
detail: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians

description: Trottoir n’est pas en pente donc pas possible de monter/descendre en fauteuil roulant

description: Pente très à-pic pour s’étendre de la piste cyclable à l’intersection pour traverser La Gappe. Pas le choix d’attendre la lumière de piéton en étant dans la pente parce que dès que le chemin devient plat, c’est dans la voie des voitures.
The direction in which the train track crosses the street is extremely dangerous for cyclists, wheelchairs and stroller as it is too easy for bike tires to get caught in the tracks.

There is no need for pedestrian beg buttons at this intersection. There are many pedestrians who need to cross most of the day and evenings, particularly to get to buses. It delays pedestrians who have to wait in the rain and sometimes miss the bus.

A member of our group using a three wheeled trike noted that the accessibility ramp from the new park down to the lower level had a sharp bend that could be hard to negotiate if you were using a mobility aid.

feature_subtype: signal - wait time to cross too long

detail: signal - wait time to cross too long

description: The island for pedestrians to wait is not large enough - often because the lights are not sequenced well for pedestrians, many are stranded on the island with little room.
This pathway is not winter maintained and often blocked by snow deposited by snow plow.
The private contractor who maintains the parking lot at Emerald Plaza, dust dump snow in front of the official pathway of the city of Ottawa.

This is a shortcut to the library that is mostly blocked by the snow plow operator who clears the mall parking. He leaves a small space but not enough to walk safely, let alone bike or wheel chair. As it is a large pile it also takes much longer before the pile is gone.
This pathway is not cleared in winter. This is a safe route that keeps people off Merivale Road, but it is dangerous to walk on let alone take a wheelchair. I highly recommend that this gets cleared.

When heading eastbound (towards LCBO) on the Industrial Ave sidewalk visibility of drivers exiting Pioneer gas station is hindered by vegetation and the large green hydro box. 

Many cars block sidewalk in order to see around the obstruction. 

Worse, drivers only look left instead of right when making their turn onto Industrial.

All throughout the Ottawa canal, queen elizabeth drive, and colonel by drive there is NOT enough lighting. Its dangerous and people can’t see anything as they are using the path. It’s dangerous as well with people sleeping in bushes and benches nearby. There are light posts but no lights. I’m really confused and this NEEDS to be fixed.

feature_subtype: obstruction - inadequate or lack of safe detour for pedestrians

Il n'y a aucun passage piétons qui permet a un piétons de partir du Boulevard du PLateau et marcher sur la rue Bruxelles jusqu'a la bibliotheque et le Parc Central. 
Il faut marcher dans la rue entre des voitures stationnés et les voitures qui circulent. 
Ce n'est pas du tout sécuritaire
detail: obstruction - inadequate or lack of safe detour for pedestrians

The curb is too steep for a motorized wheelchair.  We tried it a few times and the wheels just kept spinning.  This curb leads to the path to the Beaver Ponds - can't get there from here!

Le sentier partagé (tous les utilisateuseurs actifives) est beaucoup trop étroit. les vélos qui arrive du pont qui est de largeur acceptable se voit confiné à un entonnoir avec des marcheuseurs, vélos en sens inverse et outardes. Extrêmement dangereux!
Zone de sentier partagé inondé à chaque année, sans exceptions et donc où le passage est impossible au moins un mois à chaque printemps.
Zone de sentier partagé inondé à chaque année, sans exceptions et donc où le passage est impossible au moins un mois à chaque printemps.

Residents from 3001-3009 Jockvale and surrounding neighbourhoods must travel on a dirt shoulder or cross the road through high volume and speeding traffic to access the safe multiuse pathway leading to shopping, appointments, bus stops.  People with mobility issues, children, seniors, families and the general public face danger every time they cross the road

Glacé très glissant

Si un piétons n'appui pas sur le bouton du mendiant (beg bouton) pour traverser et que le lumière passe au vert, elle ne dure que 5 ou 6 secondes.

De plus, il y a beaucoup d'enfant dans ce cartier et le parc est de l'autre côté du boulevard des Allumetières.

6 voies à traverser.

Au croisement d’une avenue achalandée  

Circulation rapide.

Plusieurs faux arrêts par des conducteurs.

Enfant rentrant de l’école, descendu du bus RTL 60. Passé près de se faire frapper: Montrait son intention. Un premier automobiliste l’a vu, lui a fait signe de traverser. L'enfant s’est engagé. 2e voie (au centre): faux arrêt, une auto accélère sans lui laisser le passage, sans l’avoir vu. Idem quant à l'auto arrivant dans la dernière voie pour virer à gauche.

Un grand panneau et une plate-bande bloquent la vue des automobilistes qui sortent du stationnement et les empêche de voir les usagers circulant sur le trottoir vers l'ouest. En plus les autos direction ouest passent par-dessus la ligne pleine et entrent dans le stationnement, mettant doublement en danger les usagers sur le trottoir.
Absence de trottoir pour circuler dans le stationnement. Absence de passages piétonniers. Circulation très dangereuse pour les piétons partout dans le stationnement.
Piste cyclable qui traverse une intersection très passante, aucune priorité aux vélos, les automobilistes font à peine leurs stop

-Trop de circulation entre Bellechasse et Chemin Taché
-Camions lourds sensés être interdits sur rue mais pas de signalisation
-Vitesse excessive

Aucun trottoir present, impossible de prendre une marche, pourtant le sentier Nakertok se situe au 900 avenue Gatineau mais malheureusement nous devons nous y rendre en voiture malgré le fait que nous sommes situés tout pres.
pathway/sidewalk to canal has 3 steps rather than a gradual slope; this is an accessibility issue!

description: Cette intersection est dangereuse à plusieurs égards. Pour les voitures, le virage à gauche est trop serré, l'accès à la bretelle de l'autoroute est trop court, et souvent les voitures bloquent l'intersection faute de pouvoir avancer. Pour les piétons le bouton d'appel est trop près de la circulation qui est très souvent assez rapide.
Plusieurs automobilistes roulent trop rapidement sur cette rue.
Garage pail at bus stop overflowing with dog poo bags. Yuck!

Pour aller au IGA, plusieurs personnes s’aventurent dans la rue pour traverser du nord au sud et vice versa apres les emplettes. Aucune traverse piétons et aucun stop ou lumière. Le lieux est tres achallandé autant des autos, camions de livraison et pietons! Dangereux!

Les gens roulent rapidement sur l'avenue de la Drave, de nelligan jusqu'à st-rené. Les livreurs (benny's, gabriel pizza, pizza marie, etc), sont à blâmer de même que certains réisdants. La police a proposé de prendre en note les infractions et les plauqes d'immatriculations, mais ceci a mis la sécurité de certains en danger, ayant dû faire face a de l'intimidation de la part des fautifs.
Les gens roulent rapidement sur la rue nelligan et ernest-gaboury. Les livreurs (benny's, gabriel pizza, pizza marie, etc), sont à blâmer de même que certains résidants.
les gens arrivent rapidement à l'approche de la rue troyes. certains résidants doivent freiner d'urgence à la sortie de leur entrée.
les gens arrivent trop rapidement sur l'avenue de la drave en direction sud;
les gens arrivent rapidement de la rue troyes, lorsqu'ils tournent à droite sur bocage.
les gens prennent beaucoup de vitesse sur la rue vaive en direction bocage.
les gens prennent de la vitesse après l'arrêt au coin de rouville et de la drave. avant, les gens avait un meilleur sentiment de sécurité au coin de faribault et de la drave car l'arrêt y était

les gens qui sortent ou se rendent à la garderie située au bout de la rue nelligan parfois conduisent trop rapidement. de plus, les gens se dirigeant sur nelligan vers de la drave, aussi arrivent trop rapidement et ce, en dépit du passage écoleier-piétonnier.
les gens circulent rapidement sur la rue. quelques personnes ont été intimidées après avoir dénoncé la vitesse.
les gens prennent beaucoup de vitesse soit en direction de l'avenue de la drave ou du boul. de l'hôpital.

on the bike lane side of this intersection, the pedestrian crossing time is way too short. i’m a quick walker but have to sometimes jog to make it. i frequently see pedestrians stranded in the middle of the crosswalk.
This official city entrance to Emerald Plaza is often blocked by snow storage from the parking lot of the mall. A tiny dangerous unmaintained path remains over frozen stored snow.
This is the Trans Canada Trail crossing Eagleson and there is no safe crossing in the desire line
les gens circulent rapidement d'est en ouest sur bocage

Starting at this point, and ending at the mall, the paint for the bike lanes gets extremely spotty. There's a sign up, saying that it's a bike route, but it isn't maintained at all. There's a ton of leaves in the lane that I had to dodge during the entire ride. There's also almost no space between the lane and the cars parked on the side, so being doored is a constant worry.
Tons of leaves and pinecones on the road, making it tough to cycle. I had to dodge a lot the other day.

description:
Vitesse excessive en tout temps
•	Extrêmement difficile de simplement sortir de notre entré de maison pour aller porter ou chercher les enfants à l’école ou tout simplement sortir tout court.  
•	Il passe une quantité incroyable de voitures, mais également à une vitesse inacceptable, sans compter les motos qui viennent faire des ‘’Whelley’’ en été…

•	Les camions lourds qui utilisent cette voie pourtant interdite, a voir une quarantaine par jour, le bruit dérangeant qui débute vers les 4 heures du matin et qui fait en sorte que la maison tremble et qui perdure toute la journée. (je suis en télétravail depuis plus de 2 ans)

Unsafe infrastructure at the bulbout, which is paved with bricks but some of them are broken, creating a hazard for pedestrians and those in wheelchairs. Danger of toppling over due to uneven surface of infrastructure at this intersection.

description: C’est une intersection très importante pour les piétons.
Tout le monde le sait: le boulevard Saint-Paul est hyper dangereux…
C’est un endroit vraiment dangereux. Ce genre de cédez-le-passage ne devrait pas exister en dehors des autoroutes.
C’est un endroit vraiment dangereux. Ce genre de cédez-le-passage ne devrait pas exister en dehors des autoroutes.

Cet endroit représente le point de convergence entre la piste cyclable du parc Victoria/le parc linéaire de la rivière St-Charles ET le quartier St-Roch. Il est toutefois très mal conçu pour les transports actifs, et le débit de circulation est énorme et rapide.

Le problème est complexe et comprend notamment un temps de traversée trop court : il s'agit de l'intersection d'entrée d'autoroute, elle est très large, les distances à parcourir à pied sont très grandes et le tout est très très peu convivial.

feature_subtype: signal - wait time to cross too long
description: Le temps d'attente pour traverser à cette intersection est très long.  C'est une traverse stratégique pour beaucoup de piéton-nes car elle située à proximité de l'arrêt de la 800/801 et à proximité d'un escalier pour rejoindre la Basse-Ville. Cela génère des frustrations et encourage les piéton-nes à ne pas respecter la lumière pour ne pas manquer leur autobus. La visibilité est très mauvaise et les automobilistes arrivent souvent à une vitesse élevée, ce qui crée des situations dangereuses.
detail: signal - wait time to cross too long

description: L'intersection est très large, le temps de traversée est de seulement 20 à 30 secondes.
L'intersection est très large et très fréquentée par les personnes étudiantes au cégep et celles qui prennent l'autobus 800. Or le temps de traversée est nettement insuffisant.

La signalisation piétonne permettant la traversée vers l'îlot central du côté EST de l'intersection n'est pas synchronisée avec la signalisation subséquent pour effectuer le traverse complète de la route. On reste donc coincé au centre de l'intersection, qui est d'ailleurs très passante. Les véhicules roulent à. très grande vitesse et les collisions sont fréquentes.

Les traversées sont très rares sur ce tronçon et la route très longue à traverser. Particulièrement problématique au niveau de la rue Cayer : mauvaise visibilité étant donné qu'on est en haut d'une butte, et la traversée est nécessaire pour accéder à l'arrêt d'autobus.

Plusieurs personnes aînées traversent l'artère. Or, il n'y a pas de traversée sécurisée devant la résidence et les feux de circulation sont très espacés.
Le trottoir est très étroit, et les voitures roulent à une vitesse élevée ce qui crée un sentiment d'insécurité pour les piétons.

La lisibilité de l'intersection, à la fois pour les cyclistes, piétons et automobilistes, est à améliorer. De plus, l'entrée et la sortie des véhicules arrivant de l'autoroute à grande vitesse crée des confits.

description: Le boul. Milan agit comme une route rapide pour les automobilistes qui se rendent de St-Hubert vers Brossard ou vers Montréal ou vers l’autoroute 10, 30 ou 132. C’est l’unes des seules rues qui permet d’accéder à ces voies. Les arrêts sont très éloignés les uns des autres, les gens pressés dépassent la vitesse permise et font des faux arrêts. C’est dangereux puisque l’école Georges-P.-Vanier est située juste derrière et que des enfants y traversent plusieurs fois par jour.
Passage piéton et feux piétons nécessaires. Tous les feux ont été changer cette année sans y ajouter de feux piétons.
à l'approche de la garderie ou en direction de l'école l'oiseau bleu, les automobilistes circulent rapidement.
à l'approche de l'école l'oiseau bleu il faudrait diminuer la vitesse. la famille qui habite au 160 parfois peine à sortir la voiture par manque de courtoisie des automobilistes.
les véhicules prennent de la vitesse en direction vers nelligan ou st-rené. De plus, ça fait au moins 30 ans que les habitants se plaignent que les véhiculent lourds font vibrer les maison.
les automobilistes prennent beaucoup de vitesse en direction de st-rené ou vers lous-émond sur l'avenue de la drave.
les automobilistes prennent de la vitesse entre sur la rue de la futaire en direction de l'avenue de la drave ou le boul. de l'hopital.
les automobilistes prennent de la vitesse sur de bromont autant en direction ouest que est
les gens prennent de la vitesse autant en direction ouest que est.
les automobilistes prennent de la vitesse sur nelligan en direction est vers de biencourt.
C’est un axe scolaire essentiel pour les élèves à pied et à vélo, assez pour lui donner un nom éventuel si on voit grand (REV-Montréal=Rêve-Chicoute?). Université-cégep-séminaire-sainte-Bernadette.

C’est là un super sentier (méconnu par ailleurs): le vieux chemin de fer, qui traverse tout le vieux Chicoutimi-Centre. Mais toutes ses traverses piétonnes sont dangereuses. Il faudrait des avancées de trottoir (ou un dos d’âne, si on était au Mexique) ou au moins une pancarte clignotante, comme dans d’autres intersections principales. Ça vaut pour le tronçon qui traverse Jacques-Cartier, Price et Sainte-Anne. Merci :)

A cette intersection, la rue Simonds Sud est très large.  Les véhicules en direction Nord circulent parfois à double voie (même si c'est interdit).  Même si un véhicule s'arrête pour laisser passer les piétons, certains automobilistes pressés ignorent le véhicule arrêté, et le double à droite, mettant les piétons à risque.

description: Le trottoir n'a jamais été déneigé durant la moitié de l'hiver dernier. Les étudiants de l'école primaire, secondaire, cégep et université circulaient dans la rue faute de possibilité d'accéder au trottoir qui était alors un immense banc de neige.

Impossible de traverser à la lumière puisqu'il n'y a pas de lumière pour les piétons.

il est difficile parfois de tourner à gauche de beauséjour à gréber car certains automobilistes tournant à droite ne respectent pas la ligne pleine. aussi, la circulation devient lourde sur gréber, amenant certaines personnes à ''couper'' la circulation en passant dans le secteur de l'oiseau bleu en circulant rapidement.

la circulation devient lourde sur gréber, amenant certaines personnes à ''couper'' la circulation en passant dans le secteur de l'oiseau bleu en circulant rapidement sur nelligan jusqu'à ernest gaboury

There is not safe, level path of travel for pedestrians, whether on foot or using mobility devices.

feature_subtype: obstruction - inadequate or lack of safe detour for pedestrians
description: There is a two tower condo development planned for that northeast corner. which already has major traffic congestion. Already existing is a serious wind tunnel on that corner that blows people over of all sizes but is particularly harmful to frail people or small children. The sidewalk is also uneven. There have already been accidents on this corner because of the wind. The development will exacerbate this issue and most likely cause glass from windows to fall out onto the street.

description: Despite this being a major crossing for pedestrians, the button must be pushed to activate the pedestrian crossing signal. The cyclist crossing signal activates without a button being pushed. The button is hard to press and people often don't know it has to be pushed, prompting them to take dangerous risks to cross.
This a gateway to the LRT, but is not plow in the winter.
This path is not plowed in the winter, however it spans two LRT connecting paths (and the old rail bridge) that are plowed

Overall hazardous intersection. Drivers routinely ignore traffic signs and will turn in unexpected directions (as a sample, as many as 11 drivers have been tracked as driving completely against the signs in 30 minutes). They cross the meridian and cut sidewalks. Very popular spot for stunt drivers and speeding. Hazard for pedestrians/cyclists/small children using the nearby parks. Especially a problem during large events at Lansdowne. Do not assume any driver here will obey the traffic signs.

feature_subtype: drivers don't stop or yield to pedestrians
description:
This is a 2 way stop but I believe cars routinely believe it is a 4 way stop which causes cars to barely pause at the stop sign, only for cars to plow down Monk street and nearly be hit. 

Also cars park on Thornton Ave right up to the stop sign. Cars coming down Thornton dont see pedestrians about to cross until in the centre of the road. I have seen numerous near miss accidents, seen vehicles stop when they don’t have a stop sign and seen vehicles plow through when they do have a stop sign.

street parking on fifth avenue adjacent to bank, along with a separated bike lane on the other side of the road, makes travel difficult for vehicles. very frequently there is not enough room due to parked cars for two-way driving, leading to congestion that could easily be avoided through the removal of the four parking spots between Bank and Monk street

At this new building the sidewalk has been blocked by a fence and a sandwich board.

Le bois du pont devient extrêmement glissant lorsque mouillé.  La chaussé s'affaisse également.

Unsafe sidewalk - the construction on Bay has cut the road space down and busses (particularly the articulating busses) can only make the turn from Slater left onto Bay by going fully up on the sidewalk.
Bridge is missing to cross the river at this trail
La bordure n'est pas abaissée pour les cyclistes en direction sud.

Dans le sens ligne 85 vers Ottawa_ Plusieurs arrêt d'autobus (les avant, devant et après l'école) sur la rue Nelligan sont situé sur les terrains des habitants. Il n'y pas d'accès piétons pour les rejoindre pas de trottoir pas de zone sécuritaire lorsque l'on attend le bus.
Il est très (trop) dangereux de traversé a cet endroit pour rejoindre la piste cyclable ou le troitoire d'en face.

Si on veut quitter le réseau cyclable pour rejoindre le quartier oiseau-bleu on n'a le choix de contribuer sur Gréber sans piste cyclable à côtés des voitures qui roule vite ou prendre le trottoir...
L'asphalte de cette piste cyclable est en très mauvais état.

Endroit très dangereux. Aucun lien cyclable entre l'arrivée depuis la rue Nelligan et la piste cyclable du côté sud de La Gappe. Besoin au minimum d'un trottoir abaissé et de panneaux et marquages de signalisation d'une traverse.

Le segment du boul. de l'Hôpital entre la piste sur Mont-Royal (toute neuve - bravo!) et celle de La Vérendrye est dangereux pour les cyclistes. Il y a beaucoup de voitures stationnées (danger d'emportiérage) et de voitures, de camions et d'autobus.
C'est assez dangereux de se rendre à Maloney et de traverser pour accéder aux Promenades, à Pointe-Gatineau, etc., en vélo.

Intersection très peu conviviale pour les cyclistes : feux de circulation très mal adaptés et pente importante pour accéder à la piste sur le côté sud de La Gappe, et qualité d'asphalte déficiente sur la piste.

Les véhicules roulent bien trop vite malgré le dos d'âne. Il y a beaucoup de piétons qui traversent ou des enfants qui jouent dans les cours avants. Nous sommes inquiets pour les jeunes et les promeneurs.
test

Les véhicules roulent trop vite et à cause du courbe c’est difficile à voir quand les véhicules approchent, Ça fait que je suis au plein milieu du rue quand un véhicule approche très vite et je dois courir pour compléter la traverse. Avec une poussette c’est très dangereux. Pour les résidents du rue Brunante et Rue de la Châtelaine, il n’y a pas de place sécuritaire pour les piétons à croiser rue de la cote-des-neiges.

The bus shelter is in front of a vacant piece of land and so the sidewalk is not maintained. It is covered in leaves and debris which would be impossible to travel on for a wheelchair or person with a walker.
This is common place to cross (bus stops are near Cedar Glen) but the bend combined with vehicle speed makes it dangerous for pedestrians. Need a x-walk

Le trottoir de la rue de la Côte des neiges est du côté sud, donc tous les résidents au nord de la route en provenance de la rue de la Châtelaine et rue de la Brunante doivent traverser la rue pour se rendre sur le trottoir. Il n'y a pas de panneaux d'arrêt ou de passages pour piétons, et chaque intersection a une mauvaise ligne de mire avec une circulation automobile rapide. Cela rend la traversée de la rue dangereuse pour les 3 intersections.

Ce tronçon de la rue Ernest Gaboury sert à contourner l'intersection Greber-St-René-LaVérendrye aux résidents au nord.  Les automobilistes ne respectent ni l'Arrêt au coin St-René, ni la limite de vitesse de 40km-heure entre St-René et Nelligan

feature_subtype: signal - wait time to cross too long

The delay is around 2 minutes, which is understandable during rush hour, but this long delay exists during less busy times (such as noon).

description: Due to the high volume of vehicles and pedestrians at this intersection, there should be an audible pedestrian signal here.
Due to the high volume of traffic at this intersection, there should be an audible pedestrian signal here.
Countdown for the north crosswalk crossing Douglas St is only 10 seconds. Way too short considering Douglas St is 7-lanes wide.
Puisque c’est un rond point le déneigement laisse souvent à désirer.  Particulièrement au niveau du trottoir.  C’est un danger pour les bambins et les parents qui y marchent.
Accotement de la route systématiquement en mauvais état qui rend impossible ou dangereux les déplacements à pied ou à vélo.

Il y a 3 embranchements mais un seul panneau d'arrêt. Un conducteur peut arriver du nord-ouest et vouloir tourner à gauche, un autre conducteur arrive du sud et veut tourner à gauche et personne n'a à faire un arrêt.

Je suis à vélo et je pédale d'ouest en est sur la piste cyclable sur la Vérendrye. Or, les automobilistes qui circulent d'ouest en est sur la Vérendrye et qui tournent à gauche sur Ernest-Gaboury ne pensent pas à regarder qui s'en vient sur la piste cyclable de façon parallèle à eux.
Le trottoir s'arrête sur l'entrée de l'autoroute, impossible de traverser
Peu d'espace sur les côtés. Crevasses et nids de poules sur le peu d'espace.

Beaucoup trop de véhicules, incluant des véhicules lourds.
Non respect de la limite de vitesse (50)

description: Trottoirs trop étroits. Les mirroirs d'autobus sont particulièrement dangereux.

feature_subtype: conflict with vehicles turning righton red
description: Véhicules tournent à dr. au feu rouge vers le sud à partir de Lacombe. Véhicules brûlent le feu rouge sur Decelles vers le sud. Quand un véhicule sur Decelles en direction sud veut tourner à gauche sur Lacombe, les véhicules derrière lui le contournent en passant sur la piste cyclable à droite du véhicule en attente; ce faisant l'angle de leur véhicule est aligné avec un piéton qui attend pour traverser sur Lacombe vers l'est. Lorsque nous circulons à pied pour aller reprendre le pont, nous devons faire attention aux voitures qui prennent le virage et on doit régulièrement embarquer sur le gazon pour éviter une collision.
